review_title: BEWARE if adjunct or in-res non-tenure faculty
job_title: Instructor in residence in Storrs, CT
pros: UConn has an excellent reputation and looks great on your CV. FT benefits are excellent. Storrs & Hartford campuses are vibrant and fun places to teach. Classrooms generally up-to-date. Students are generally engaged depending on campus. Many teaching development (e.g. lunch & learns) programs that also expose you to other schools and departments. Teaching online has good training, tech, and faculty support but pay is poor. Adjuncts full access to libraries, email, software from until 1 term after last semester. Online or in-person, it's a lot of work for little pay often based on random student evals (SETs) which are only used for non-tenured faculty.
cons: Three major things: PAY SUCKS with no security, HR has no power, and research rules far above teaching. Research is God, and change is not welcome. Tenured faculty rule everything, There is a HUGE difference between non tenure-track/tenured (NTT) and tenure-track/tenured faculty (TT). Adjuncts are in their own group at the very bottom with no support, no rights, no security. NTT Instructors/Professors in Residence are paid 40% of new, inexperienced PhD TT, 30% of average tenured BASE salary depending on school . . I was teaching 7 classes, 4 courses, 350 students; advising 60; overseeing 5 honors theses; actively serving on 2 school committees and then still had to "publish or perish." TT teach 3, nothing else but research/publish. Tenured find small roles like Program Director to reduce course load to 3 + a few advisees + 1 comm. BIG SUCK: By AAUP's contract, NTT faculty can receive max 5 annual contracts; then they go multi-year (3 & 5 yr). Multi-year contracts include nice but very expensive perks like paid sick leave. THE KICKER: depts & colleges don't want the risk & cost of multi-year contracts, usually preferring to hire new NTT on contracts that require more work for lower salary & perks. Thus typically first 2 evals include a small random thing to improve. At the 3rd eval (4th yr for AY5 contract) they can say warnings weren't corrected and not renew, avoiding the multi-year cost and commitment REGARDLESS OF WHAT YOU DO. HR, well, forget it. A tenured faculty was harassing me: drunk dialing, cursing, email spyware, & finally personal threats. I followed procedure: dept head (their best friend), HR, AAUP. HR said tenured faculty, no can do. Dept head told me I had no proof and no one would believe me. Union wrote a letter to my file for me. Salaries are well below market, and the culture is dysfunctional. It's a solo gig designed by people who don't like working with others. No teams, rare to see or interact with colleagues. Faculty only come to campus for meetings, class, and office hours and keep to themselves. Student eval scores (SET) are the core of dept reviews. Teaching quality is not valued nor recognized in evals regardless of awards. You have to really love teaching to come to UConn because you won't be paid or treated well, there's a 4 year unspoken contract limit, you jump through hoops to get the position, and the benefits aren't worth it.

pros: Working for the University of Connecticut can be a positive experience if you are a seasoned professor or if you can handle thinking on your feet and enjoy autonomy. Working at the Stamford campus has its benefits over working at the main campus. Namely, the campus is urban and your classes will have a diverse population of students who are eager to learn.
cons: The state limits adjunct professors from teaching more that 9 credit hours so your potential for growth--especially if the university is undergoing a budget overhaul--are terribly limited. Again, the Stamford campus is hands down a better environment if you enjoy autonomy and students that are in your class to learn. The main campus can be less diverse and depending on your department, you might be stuck working in a non-diverse, overly judgemental environment with co-workers who are cold, competitve and unhelpful.

review_title: Rigorous PhD Biomedical Science Program (but heavily lab-dependent)
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Farmington, CT
pros: UConn Health's PhD Biomedical Science Program is an unbrella program that allows you to explore multiple areas of concentration - Genetics and Developmental Biology, Cell Biology, Molecular Biology and Biochemistry, Immunology, Neuroscience, Skeletal and Craniofacial Biology. During your first year, you get to do up to three rotations (one per semester including the summer). Once you decide on the area of concentration and the lab for your thesis research, you continue onto a full-time doctoral thesis research while taking required classes for the specific area of concentration.
cons: This is not specific to UConn Health only - rather a general issue when it comes to gradschool for life sciences. Most of the time, success during gradschool is determined by the type of relationship you have with your primary investigator (PI) and the nature of your project. Make the most of the rotations during the first year - make sure to some homework (don't just read their papers - talk to the lab people!). Also, grant situation is getting tougher as years go by. Make sure to ask your potential PI about the current funding status of the lab and also in near future.

review_title: Great part-time job at UConn if you love sports.
job_title: Intramural & Special Events Supervisor in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros: Intramurals at UConn gives those students who enjoy sports and/or officiating a chance to develop their officiating skills in a comfortable environment. Although some games become competitive and therefore participants tend to get "wordy" over certain calls made and disagree with how things turn out, supervisors and department management will always back you on what happened. Supervisors teach you everything you need to know and between games (or quarters/halves) they point out little things you should work on. You will have a chance to move up within a year or two to supervisor. It's a fun place to work and you meet alot of people from around campus. For the most part, the amount you work and the schedule you work is completely up to you which is convenient.
cons: Some of the downsides to working here are the hours, the pay, and the participants getting angry. Intramurals run on a late night schedule to avoid conflicts with classes, so normal hours are 5:30 pm - 11:30 pm Sunday through Thursday. For some of us, this is no problem. For others, this conflicts with the college lifestyle of going out late during the week or having time to do homework/study during the evening. The pay for working here is slightly above minimum wage, so for the verbal abuse you may encounter from participants at times and the physical tole it takes on you to run around for six hours on a court or field, it can be a rough trade off. At the end of the day though, it's still a fun college part time job.

pros:
If you're lucky and your faculty adviser has enough funds, you will live a relatively comfortable life as a Graduate Assistant. The full (20 hrs/wk) salary is quite sufficient in my opinion. After all it's graduate school and you're getting paid to conduct research and work towards your degree.
Recently the Graduate Employee Union was able negotiate better terms for GAs. Health insurance has improved.
cons: If your faculty adviser is running out of funds, then expect to live a miserable life. The university allows GAs to be employed at a minimum rate of 10 hrs/wk. That means half the salary a full GA position receives, which is truly a pathetic amount. Add on top of this a ridiculous amount of term fees that are not covered by tuition waivers, and you're looking at a salary that is below the federal poverty level. Now if a 10 hrs/wk appointment truly meant that the GA is only dedicating 10 hours a week to their work. this might not seem such a bad deal. However everyone knows that every GA pretty much works about 40 hrs/wk...

review_title: Graduate Assistant at the Storrs campus
pros: Pay is sufficient to live on (if you rent with a roommate), relaxed work atmosphere, everyone's really great and willing to direct you/help you. Some departments give additional grants to their grad students which is awesome. You can get interest-free short-term loans from the Graduate Student Senate (up to $1500 to be repaid in three months with a possibility of a one-month extension last I was there). A lot of opportunity to engage and grow if you want to. 100% paid health care insurance.
cons: Most graduate assistants only get 15 hrs/week and don't get paid over the summer break. They process your health care insurance that they pay for you as a grant so you end up paying taxes on it. School is in the middle of nowhere pretty much. Lack of graduate student housing and the housing near campus is expensive so a lot of folks end up living in Willimantic which sucks if you don't have a car since the most useful buses get overcrowded on a daily basis, plus, Willimantic, despite some good qualities, is a wee bit crimey.

pros: good place to work here
cons: sometimes can be frustrating though

pros: The benefits are state benefits and are ridiculously generous but don't wonder why they are "broke". All that costs an insane amount of money.
cons: Very elitist environment if you work in the schools, clinics, or hospital. Very few docs and administrators will respect staff.  Most treat staff like children.  Overall they treat everyone like hourly employees. If you are a mid level professional who has current skills, you will be surrounded with people with ancient skills.  You will never be rewarded for doing your job well, being conscientious or going above and beyond.  Someone who knows less than you and works less than you probably makes so much more than you because the state rewards service and NEVER performance.    The union membership is "optional" meaning if you decline membership, you can't vote and you will STILL pay dues.  The union president and vp make so much money that  it will make you puke given that they don't have much control or influence in anything and in more recent times skill nor the ability to negotiate.

review_title: Support for graduate assistants getting better
pros: Lots of support from the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources (the college in which I was based), but when I was there, the support from the Graduate School was just getting better.  Since the graduate students there unionized, it may be better, but I'm not sure.  Lots of technology resources (virtual computers and virtual networks).  Very helpful library staff.
cons: Everyone knows that a 20 hour graduate assistantship doesn't mean you only work 20 hours; yet even with this understanding, many of my colleagues felt the assistantship stipends were only slightly competitive.  The biggest complaint when I was there was that assistantship stipends weren't increasing relative to inflation and the very rapid increases in student fees from year to year.  It also wasn't always clear what your student fees went towards and how you benefited from them.

review_title: Great Experience as a Student Worker
job_title: Student Administrative Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: As a student, I was able to work and attend school. The position was not demanding but it was challenging enough for me to gain a lot of administrative experience. Hours were structured around my schedule.
cons: UConn is always changing around their vendors and benefits providers to get the best deals. I didn't have to go through any of the difficulties due to those changes as a student. Their hiring process isn't the best at checking backgrounds/personalities of the hired. In a few cases, professors did not match their job qualifications- I understand however that this is a time restraint issue. Some of the upper level management, professors and department heads are entitled/bully their way into always being right. So in some work environments, there exists friction between certain people.

pros: Free housing plus stipend, single room to yourself in most situations, access to personal development training, priority in certain campus event seating, ability to make a change in residents' lives if you get a good group, tight-knit staffs
cons: ResLife is becoming more and more micro-managing, hall directors and upper management treats RAs like they are children incapable of making decisions on their own about their residents, unorganized training and event structure, departmental decisions and policies are often inefficient, claims "you are a student first" but gives unreasonable expectations on RA-related work, annoying push of extremely liberal ideas relating to social justice and privilege (villainized if you do not agree with it all), basically everybody hates you before getting to know you because you're the RA

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros: The benefits are outstanding.  The health insurance is through the state of Connecticut, so the premiums and deductables are small.  WIth rising healthcare costs, this is a very valuable benefit!  The tuition benefit is also a huge plus for anyone looking to advance tehir career or who has children college age or soon to be college age.  The atmosphere is friendly.  My supervisor provided good feedback and was easy to work with.  The organization is so large that there is always a career advancement opportunity.
cons: Being a state institution, there are a lot of regulations.  The location of Storrs is out of the way, so unless you plan to live in the area (not a bad idea - cheap real estate) you will have a real commute.

review_title: A good place overall for doctorate research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: Smart and even world famous people to work with. High academic requirements with great industrial collaborations. A variety of student recreation facilities to build your body. The basketball teams are famous.
cons: Engineering departments are relatively small. You may have to spend a lot of time fulfilling the course requirements that are not quite relevant to your research projects, and then spend additional time learning relevant materials by yourselves. Together with the high publication requirements, you may spend more than 5 years on your PhD study!

review_title: 18 years, have no intention of leaving
pros: wonderful people to work with. I have worked here 18 years in October. I've been paid by grant, so my job is pretty secure, as long as I work hard, and well. But every 4-5 years it gets scary, what is going to happen to the grant? Is a Republican congress going to cut the budget again, and the NIH is going to get cut, Science is going to get cut, and am I going to lose my job? It almost happened last year. But I was saved, and I have a job for the next 4 years, as long as I do my job well, and a Republican congress doesn't pander to the teaparty.
cons: parking can be a pain in the butt.

review_title: The administration does not value graduate students but a nice place to work if you have a good department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: There are modern buildings with the top departments having great work spaces. The campus itself is beautiful. There is a new Storrs city center that was build right off campus. This increased the number of restaurants and services. It is easy to commute (mostly traffic free and through beautiful woods) from the Hartford area if you have a car.
cons: There are extremely high student fees taken out of graduate paychecks even when tuition is waved. The health insurance coverage for graduate students is poor. For many places it is cheaper to tell the healthcare provider that you do not have insurance. A graduate student union was just formed though it seems the administration plans on continuing to take advantage of graduate students anyway.

review_title: Great people but sclerotic management and lackadaisical effort between semesters makes it hard to recommend.
pros: Location. You can't beat the scenery around Storrs in the Fall.  The newly built "downtown" opens up options for real restaurants, allowing you to skip the dining halls for lunch. Lots of amenities if you utilize the campus.
cons: I know all large organizations have issues, but given that this one has built in breaks where the workload really does fall off, or at least diminishes in pressure, managers should be all over process and workflow improvements.  Any other organization would kill for that kind of down time to be able to effect internal change. Lots of missed opportunities and problems tend to accumulate for no good reason.

pros: As a student worker, the department I worked for really held the "school first" mentality. Always flexible and looking to build a solid schedule around my coursework and school activities. Full-time workers were knowledgeable and extremely supportive to the student staff. Great way to make connections within the school and learn a lot of the inner workings of the university structure. Solid compensation with good raises while employed. Great perks such as lunches, speakers, advice from professionals, and a casual, friendly culture (matches the college culture well).
cons: University hierarchy and bureaucracy always felt like it was getting in the way. It felt like things were fairly slow to change. It technically is a state job.

pros: Great location, 90 minutes from boston, but in a quiet, safe, bucolic location in northeast corner of ct.  Salaries are fair, and campus is accessible and attractive. Uconn has a high school spirit, and aspirations of greatness.
cons: Dependent on funding beyond the tuition, the fees for students are high and budget for departments is terrible. Lack of cohesive plan to move agenda forward points to leadership voids.

review_title: UITS Web and Mobile Services team
pros:
While working on UConn’s Web and Mobile Services team, I used HTML5, CSS3, SASS, Github, WordPress, Squarespace and more in the completion of projects. UITS Web and Mobile Services has allowed me a broad range of project opportunities. My time in the Web and Mobile Services team provided an opportunity to collaborate with great designers and developers. The job exposed me to myriad development and creation methodologies, including interaction design, user experience, and agile methodology. It was constant process, development, and learning which I love.

It was really a great place with amazing people.
cons: University of Connecticut, like any other college, has many branding regulations which you have to hurdle. It can be a good challenge but can also be bothersome if you want to try new things.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: Excellent health insurance plan ever since the graduate assistants unionized.
cons: Parking is awful. There are very few paid research positions available, at least in the physics department, so plan on working 60 hour weeks (20 teaching, 20 classroom, 20 research) if you want to get your PhD in 4 years.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: Great people to work with. I say this as the professors that you will be doing research with are top notch, and have studied at the best universities. The fellow graduate students you will interact with are also above average.
cons: This place is located in a remote area of Connecticut. This is not near any major city, even if you count Hartford as a city which it is barely. The administration sucks and the research facilities are slowly improving.

job_title: Help Center Lead in Storrs, CT
pros: Flexible work hours as a student, lots of opportunity for growth as a dedicated undergrad
cons: If you are just looking for a student job, it can be ok - but you won't exceed making tier 2/3 pay (~$11-13). The next level is student management which is very demanding for a small pay increase. It used to be an amazing place to work with lots of opportunities for learning for students, but now it seems to be moving without great direction.

review_title: Graduate research assistant in the Physics department
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: The Physics department has a lot of options if one is looking into experimental Physics. The prime fields are ultrafast laser, atomic and molecular optics, condensed matter, and nuclear physics. The theoretical side is a bit weak at the moment due to retirement of some faculty members. The department in general is accommodating to graduate students' needs. The qualifying exams (also known as 'prelims') are pretty standard. Most of the professors, especially those with continuing funding, are welcoming to new students.
cons: The location of the university is a bit remote. The nearest non-university apartment complex is about 15 minutes away by car. Thus, it is very difficult to lead a fluid lifestyle without a car.

review_title: Nice and isolated university with low income but good medical coverage for employees
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros:
A college town and weather is nice in (Short) spring, hot and humid in the summer, nice again in (Short) fall. winter is so BRUTAL!
Friendly staff on campus. The ideal place just to study and and get your PhD because pretty much nothing is happening in that area.
cons: In the middle of nowhere, so quiet town and mostly state park Forrest state. If you get bored you can just study or drive to NYC or Boston.

job_title: Assistant Professor In Residence in Storrs, CT
pros: Flexible hours, 4 months of vacation, chance to help students become great.
cons:
In the engineering school, we were expected to get perfect student ratings, but management didn't care about quality.  No exceptions or modifications were made for the type or size of the course.
We were expected to kowtow to tenured faculty.
Expected to be available through email constantly.
However, management would frequently refuse to answer questions through email.
Management would violate the union contract to get rid of anyone that didn't satisfy those perfect student ratings.
Management lied to the faculty union to avoid confrontation.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros:
Lots of opportunities for graduate students to gain experience to prepare themselves for future careers.
Many collaborative research efforts between departments.
Many PIs are flexible about the time of day to start labwork.
The amount of work you put in shows-whether in the lab, classroom, or teaching environment.
cons:
There is some conflict between departments concerning the allocation of resources and requirements to complete degrees.
It is essential to go out of your way to find out about pay during the summer months.
Problems found in teaching material one semester may not be corrected for the next.

review_title: Low pay for adjuncts and Cooperating teachers
job_title: Adjunct Instructor/Cooperating Teacher in Glastonbury, CT
pros: Overall, I love the students and feel appreciated by the professors with whom I work.
cons: Low pay for adjuncts is true almost everywhere. However, for Cooperating Teachers, those public school teachers who host student teachers are paid a very small fee. Some colleges offer a free course every time you take a student teacher. That equals thousands of dollars and doesn't cost the University anything. It would pay off for the cooperating teacher in professional development, getting back after giving so much, and eventually an increase in salary after a certain number of credits are earned. We deserve that.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Farmington, CT
pros: A very collaborative environment and a great PhD program in Immunology. You get to learn a lot from students and all the professors. Flow cytometry facility and all core facilities are easily accessible and greatly managed. So its very easy to get to use instruments needed for your work.
cons: Projects in all the labs may not be directly applicable to human work or their may not be any disease connection to your work. Which can come in your way when you are competiting with other students after PhD to find jobs. But research done is sound and good and one gets to learn  lot.

review_title: Not a place to build a career, but a nice place to work.
job_title: Student Worker in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros: Working at University Catering is very low-stress, straight-forward work with a decent pay and very flexible hours.  Working as a student worker allows you to get some extra cash, new friendships, and free food while a student or living around a campus.  Any catering experience will help if you want or need to take up a job as a waitress or bartender, and does help you learn to get along with a variety of people.
cons: There is very limited growth potential and little opportunity to apply acquired skills to other jobs.

review_title: Working at the UConn Ice Rink was the best experience I have had with work culture and employees.
pros: The people are great, easy job, great for students looking for a source of income and a new group of friends. Not a lot of hours unless you request to have more, which is nice when balancing classes too.
cons: Minimum wage or slightly higher pay is low, but the job is easy so it is completely fair. Only hires students, and not very many. Dealing with customers is not always the easiest. Late night and early morning hours possible.  You will work most weekends, often early in the morning or at night.

review_title: Experience depends highly on your advisor
pros:
-There are a few really great professors to work with
-Free gym on campus with good equipment
-Lots of great places to eat on campus
cons:
-Many students are taken advantage of by their advisors, especially international students. This is not only from the amount of work required, but also the extreme rudeness from some of them. Hope you have a thick skin if you end up working for one of them.
-Encountered several office administrators who have no idea what they are doing. Verify in writing whatever any of them tell you, since half the time they're wrong.
-Facilities are not state of the art, so if your research requires good equipment then I recommend looking elsewhere.

review_title: Great pay (for a grad student), great benefits!
pros: Good working environment, great pay and benefits.  I will take a pay cut if I adjuct here after I graduate.
cons: Top heavy UCONN continues the "industry-wide" trend of sliding into corporatism.  Emphasis of athletics sometimes outweighs more pressing concerns.  Also the student body is rather homogenous.  Adjucts make more than many colleges around Connecticut but they should still pay more.

review_title: Job was a bit tedious and the Bureaucracy gets old, overall it could have been a lot worse
job_title: Client Service Representative in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros: Consistent pay, no prior experience needed. Good experience for me as a college kid in a real world environment.
cons: Bureaucracy was crazy at times. Very little communication between closely related departments and a serious disconnect between the directors of the departments and the workers. The clients who called in were often very frustrated with the process and with us as it was not really very user friendly.

pros: The free food, flexible schedule, relaxed management. They give you a bonus check at the end of the semester of .25 for every hour you've worked.
cons: The full time management is over-bearing and has unrelastic expectations of their workers. They will expect you to miss classes to work. They want you to be working non-stop and if they see you with nothing to do they have give you a very unpleasant job.

review_title: it's like living with a dysfunctional family
pros:
Salaries are way above average and exceed anything in the private sector
great benefits
cons: Deans and Vice Provosts have supreme power and encourage a toxic environment through their lack of management skills and their interest in encouraging dissent and long-standing disputes.  Deans/VP's have what they fondly call a "slush fund" which enables them to reward their staff with "merit pay".  They do not have to defend how they distribute merit pay and unlike in the private sector where "bonuses" are one time lump sums of money - "merit pay" is added to the base salary.  Which creates a very contentious environment.

review_title: Review for University of Connecticut as a graduate research assistant and a graduate teaching assistant .
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: Nice working environment which is full of nice people. The university is situated in a very nice location which has easy access to Hartford area .
cons: The main issues are with the parking and Insurance. The old insurance plan we had was really nice, however the new plan does not cover most of the problems (dental etc.) The parking lots are situated far a way. Hard to walk on snowy, cold days. (specially when shuttles are limited during when undergrads are away)

pros: UConn recently hired a large number of new faculty and has been investing a lot of money supporting science, technology, engineering and math research and graduate training programs.  The faculty are supportive and dedicated to teaching, mentoring, research and service.  The undergraduate University is in a beautiful rural area in the Notheastern quiet corner of CT.  Lots of hiking, running? biking and kayaking.
cons: rursl setting makes it hard to attract graduate students and post docs.  Other institutes for science collaborations and interactions are far (in Boston or Nee York)

review_title: Exciting & Friendly Place to Work. Benefits are in Top 10%
pros: Workplace camaraderie is above expectations and not the usual day to day boredom. Vibrant community, student interaction is always positive & friendly. Salary is fantastic, benefits and their cost are incredible. Retirement healthcare & pension assures me of a smooth retirement.
cons: Too much emphasis on making outside beautiful while inside buildings are in dire need of improvements.

review_title: Student labor that has actual meaning and experience
pros:
Extremely flexible with work scheduling for students
Good learning opportunity
There is a wide variety of work types from business to manual labor
The student labor positions offer students the ability to have some level of income while attending school
cons:
Under-utilization of student skills
Regulations on the involvement of students in certain work areas
Compensation is usually around minimum wage. With the few hours that students are working each week, the income is very minimum, and can only cover small expensive

pros: Fun spontaneous environment where anything and everything can happen.  New students are being hired all the time which brings new friendships.  Management is very understanding and as long as you are responsible you are set to earn more than any other student on campus.
cons: Sometimes you will be yelled at for things that are really minuscule.  Student management sometimes oversteps there boundaries, long hours on a bus combined with a radio that don't work well (inaudible) can make you a little insane.  Balancing Work, school, and college life is frustrating.

review_title: A great University to work at while a student
pros: Everything: the culture, the people, the projects and the large budgets with little constraint with which we worked offered us flexibility and freedom.
cons: Sometimes upper management seemed like they had been distanced from the first line employees and offered little interaction or advice, that is probably more a function of the intense schedules they held rather than their lack of interest

review_title: Difficult to navigate for people who are unaware of big-university bureaucratic shortcomings
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros:
Autonomy, usually. If you show up as an experienced teacher, then you should have no issues getting settled with the teaching load that most departments give their grad students--teach 2, take 3. If, however, you have never been in a classroom it is rather like baptism by fire because there is little-to-no training for brand new grad students.
If you are an independent person who not only has a car but also takes out some student loans, it is possible to live a semi-comfortable life on the salary provided. This is a big university and, as such, you have to make your own opportunities. No one will hold your hand. UConn is a rank 1 university. You have access to some very brilliant minds who are extremely well published in their fields but you really have to have a plan and be independent to 'get along' in the Storrs, CT wilderness.
cons: If you are a person who needs a really active adviser and some hand holding, this is not the university for you. This is a rank one facility and its faculty are focused mainly on publishing and not too terribly on teaching. Depending on your department, you will work like a dog and be expected to produce in a timely fashion. If you can separate the wheat from the chaff you will be in good shape. Unfortunately, there is a lot of administrative chaff---administrative assistants that should have long ago retired, professors who are overwhelmed and live so far away that they are never available and, finally, professors who are so far removed from today's doctoral job market that they cannot really provide productive advice for a young scholar. Sad, but true.

job_title: Correctional Head Nurse in Cheshire, CT
pros: Benefits, salary, overtime, unionized, & excellent retirement pay.  We work well together.  No one eats their young here. I love the fact that if I have a real sick inmate I ship him out.  Supervisors listens to us staff nurses & try to make our experience better.
cons: Correctional nursing can be challenging & is not for timid people.  You have to have good judgement & some previous work experience or inmates will play games with you.

review_title: Community driven non-profit organization; research, education, hospital all in one
pros: There are always lots of resources available to help employees with any problems they might have. Especially during covid, the health center really cares about the mental well-being of their employees and there are mental health professionals to talk to, daily meditations, online coffee hours; lots of opportunities to connect with fellow employees and have a sense of community.
cons: Parking can be tough. Employees are technically state employees and we have a union; not necessarily a bad thing, I just never really understood what this does for us.

pros: You spend most of your time preparing for class and you get to determine when those times are mostly by your self. The teaching is enriching as you see students develop skills they did not have before.
cons: The pay is very low. You are a student and that cast should also be factored in but you feel like you are being well underpaid for the work you do both in and out of the classroom.

review_title: There are a lot of educational assignment and professional tasks, many challenges but great feeling of achievement!!
job_title: Graduate Assistant in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros:
The faculty members are very nice and responsible for giving tasks.
They not  just give you the assignment, but they also help me and lead me to the right track.
cons:
The location is absolutely a negative element, parking issues.
There is efficiency space to improve. Overall, the experience is very good and with much more positivity than negativity.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Farmington, CT
pros: Teaching facility and state benefits
cons: State buget problem trickle down to the hospital bugets. This negativity impacts RN staffing and the ancillary support availability. This inadvertently lends itself to potential unsafe senarios, delay of care and other safety issues.

review_title: My experience at the University of Connecticut was noteworthy and enjoyable.
pros: The staff in the Department of Recreation is always a pleasure to work with. The work environment constantly maintains a positive and growing attitude, which shows in all its employees.
cons: Sometimes the shifts at the Department of Recreation can last into the wee hours of the night.  While this can be avoided, there is general sentiment among management that all employees should take these later shifts.

review_title: Really depends on where you work
pros: Lots of different options of on-campus jobs for students.  It's easy to get a job in a dining hall if you don't need a ton of income, just some spending money.
cons: Can be bureacratic.  Most people stay away from one of the area managers.  You can leave work feeling absolutely exhausted without feeling appreciated by upper management (really depends on who is managing on that particular day).  You definitely can't use a lot of these jobs to pay for college without severely compromising your study time.

pros: You feel as if you are helping society and this makes up for the so, so salary.  Good benefits.  Not too much of a Big Brother atmosphere.
cons: Faculty and staff at the regional campus feel that though thier voices are heard, they aren't valued if they don't help Storrs.  We are basically told what to do from Storrs and don't have much control.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Storrs, CT
pros: I studied at Uconn for five years for my PhD in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering. The department has good reputation and graduate programs that providing various opportunities for professional growth. The professors and staff are very friendly, open-minded, and willing to help students. I have had pleasant experience studying here.
cons: Storrs is a very beautiful town, but its location is a bit far from big stores or malls. It make take you at least 20-30 minutes to drive there, so driving a car seems to be necessary.

pros: Working at UConn is a fantastic environment that allows you to grow as a person and as a professional. The work environment is work hard, play hard. The people are smart and do their jobs and care about you as a person.
cons: The pay isn't great, but what do you expect for the school paying for your education? Also, you need to be prepared to put in long hours to be successful in this job.

review_title: Very fun working at the Student Union

cons: Because the University does not run on a full year schedule (which of course is good), student employees compete for hours during non-academic periods of the year because the Union is open year-round.

review_title: If you're serious about your career go somewhere else for grad school

review_title: Great place to start, horrible place to develop
job_title: Web Programmer in Storrs Mansfield, CT

Very friendly co-workers and supervising staff

Very intuitive and meaningful development projects aimed towards the overall well-being of students
cons:
No room for growth
Does not support the ability to gain certification through job; have to do so on your own

review_title: Paying Union Dues is a Waste of time at UConn
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Storrs Mansfield, CT

cons: Parking distance from office. Politics. Total disregard by Sr Management for the activities of Middle Management - they get away with mind-blowing activities.

pros: I enjoy a lot of autonomy, the salary is fine, and faculties (especially my mentors) in my department are mostly nice and helpful.

Also, the new online student evaluation system is really confusing.  Also, if your mentor/adviser/PI has no "political influence" in school or in department, you are almost dead.  It is unfair sometimes.

review_title: I love the environment and the people I work with.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Storrs Mansfield, CT
pros: I am a student worker and Uconn is very accomodating to my school scehdule. I am allowed to pick and choose when I work. I am allowed to take time off for summer/spring/thanksgiving/winter break vacations or choose to work full time.
cons: I can only work 20 hours or less during the school semester. Also, if i were to discontinue my studies at the Univesity of Connecticut I would lose my position here as a student worker.

review_title: Not positive, not totally negative. I would not do it again.
pros: Good benefits, It is challenging and enjoyable to interact with students. It is not hard to travel to interesting places nearby.
cons: Management versus union battles get tiring quickly. Being a state employee restricts creativity and innovation. There is no general feeling that any good is being done. Money is routinely wasted.

review_title: University of Connecticut is a great place to work at. Please come, visit and stay. You will like it.
pros: Storrs is a small town far from the distractions and is a perfect place to study. People here are nice and helpful. Grocery store and CVS are close to the campus. For college basketball fans, we have strong men's and wonmen's basketball team.

pros: Lots of time off, great benefits, low intensity work. The campus is beautiful, and the open, democratic culture of a university is great.
cons: There is very little incentive to do great work. Promotions are locked into a union contract, and it is impossible for departments to fire underperforming workers. This leads to a general culture of just getting by, which can be frustrating.

review_title: Custodian for 3 years. Great place to work. Union shop with fantastic benefits.
pros: Fantastic Union benefits and great people. Retirement and retirement healthcare is an awesome benefit. Beautiful and safe campus to work on.
cons: Very hard to advance as it only goes by seniority rather than merit. Never any appreciation for the work we do, we are the backbone of this university.

job_title: Applications Analyst II in Farmington, CT
pros: Awesome benefits, union helps you get regular raises , opportunity for growth if you are a hard worker and educated.

review_title: Work/Life balance and ample fringe benefits
pros:
Remote, semi-rural location.
35 hour work week.
Tons of vacation time.
Super-high retirement contribution matching.

The specific benefits vary according to what union you're in (Yes you have to be in a union to work here).  Many salaried employees, like me, are in UCPEA, whose benefits are fantastic.
cons:
Remote, semi-rural location.
Not much in the way of career trajectories within the organisation.
Just as bureaucratic and top-heavy as any other state organisation.

Your colleagues might be clockwatchers or underachievers, depending on what group you're in.

pros: Freedom to work and execute my job, working with faculty and staff to access grants.
cons: The University is very stove piped and competitive between departments and professors to the detriment of their relationships and opportunities with industry.

pros: New Employees want to make a difference and try to bring positive change.  The new buildings are beautiful and the patient care is good.

pros: Professional, great benefits, nice coworkers, mission of workplace to help others obtain excellent healthcare. review_title: Good place to work but expect no hikes
